title: 105_hr1943
content: The Act is titled the "Carlsbad Irrigation Project Acquired Land Transfer Act" and involves conveyance. The Carlsbad Irrigation Project Acquired Land Transfer Act allows the Secretary of the Interior to convey acquired lands and facilities to the Carlsbad Irrigation District, including the irrigation and drainage system, ditch rider houses, maintenance shop, buildings, and Pecos River Flume. The Secretary retains surface rights and storage/flow easements for lands under Brantley and Avalon dams in Eddy County, New Mexico. Conveyance terms are based on the 1978 Bureau of Reclamation report. Terms and Conditions of Conveyance state that the conveyed lands must be managed for the Carlsbad Project purposes and the District assumes rights and obligations from the United States related to managing certain lands near Brantley Reservoir for fish and wildlife purposes. The District assumes rights and obligations from the United States for managing lands near Brantley Reservoir for fish and wildlife purposes. The District is not obligated for financial support or entitled to any revenues from agreements with the Secretary. The Congress expects the Secretary to complete the conveyance authorized by the Act within 9 months. If not done, a report detailing encountered problems and steps to complete the conveyance must be submitted within 30 days. SEC. 3. LEASE MANAGEMENT AND PAST REVENUES COLLECTED FROM THE ACQUIRED LANDS. The Secretary of the Interior must identify and notify leaseholders of mineral and grazing leases within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. The District will assume all rights and obligations of the United States for existing leases on acquired lands and will receive receipts from such leases for authorized purposes. The District will also adhere to current mineral leasing regulations. The District will continue to adhere to current mineral leasing regulations for the Carlsbad Project. Receipts in the reclamation fund will be made available to the District as credits towards its operation and maintenance obligations until depleted. Receipts from mineral and grazing leases on acquired lands will be received by the United States before conveyance. The Secretary can use up to $200,000 for implementing the Act, with the rest going into the reclamation fund for the District's operation and maintenance credits to the United States. SEC. 4. WATER CONSERVATION PRACTICES. The Secretary may spend up to $100,000 annually for water conservation practices at the Carlsbad Project, with the District providing matching funds. The District can voluntarily implement water conservation practices without limitations. The United States will not be liable for damages related to conveyed lands, except for negligence prior to conveyance. This does not increase liability beyond the Federal Tort Claims Act.
